title: 104_hr4166
content: The Act titled "Stop Sweatshops Act of 1996" references the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938. The Act includes findings related to sweatshops. The Congress finds that garment production violating labor standards hinders commerce and fair competition, leading to poor working conditions in the domestic garment industry. Most sweatshop employers fail to comply with recordkeeping requirements under the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938. The amendment of the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is necessary to hold manufacturers accountable for compliance with wage and hour laws in the garment industry, promoting fair competition and better working conditions for workers. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to establish legal responsibility for compliance with wage and hour provisions in the garment industry. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to hold manufacturers in the garment industry liable for violations committed by contractors in garment manufacturing operations. Manufacturers are subject to civil liability and penalties for violations of labor standards related to industrial homework and other provisions. Manufacturers in the garment industry are responsible for the production of apparel, excluding pre-manufactured items like buttons and zippers. The term 'manufacturer' refers to any person who contracts with a contractor to produce clothing and accessories for sale. The term 'manufacturer' in the garment industry refers to individuals responsible for producing apparel, excluding pre-manufactured items like buttons and zippers, to be sold. The term 'contractor' refers to individuals who work with manufacturers to produce various types of apparel, while 'retailer' refers to those who sell apparel to consumers. The liability to employees is addressed in Section 16 of the U.S. Code. The liability of manufacturers in the garment industry to employees is expanded in the amended subsections. Manufacturers are now jointly and severally liable if a contractor violates certain sections in the production of apparel. This includes liability for violations by manufacturers in the garment industry. Manufacturers in the garment industry are now jointly and severally liable for violations by contractors in apparel production. This liability can also extend to manufacturers themselves. Manufacturers in the garment industry are now jointly and severally liable for violations by contractors in apparel production. Section 16(e) is amended to impose civil penalties for failure to maintain payroll records as required under section 11(c). Penalties include up to $1000 per employee for violations and higher fines for submitting fraudulent payroll records. Effective date of these provisions is specified. The amendments made by this Act will take effect 30 days after its enactment.
